newsitem.title: AFGHANISTAN: Taleban reject ultimatum, say no Kabul evacuation.
newsitem.headline: Taleban reject ultimatum, say no Kabul evacuation.

text.p: Kabul's Taleban rulers on Wednesday rejected an ultimatum by ousted government forces to abandon the capital, and said they had no plans to evacuate the city.

Acting information minister Amir Khan Mutaqi told Reuters the Taleban had enough forces to defend the city. He was responding to a reported call by Ahmad Shah Masood to leave the city or face bloodshed.

Masood was the military chief in the ousted government of President Burhanuddin Rabbani. The British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) quoted Masood, whose forces have pushed the Taleban back towards Kabul in a dogged offensive this week, as demanding on Tuesday that the purist Islamic movement withdraw from the city or face bloodshed and destruction.
"This type of ultimatum does not have any significance. If it had then we would not have set up our movement," Mutaqi said.
He said that Kabul was peaceful and dismissed Masood's ultimatum as propaganda. He said such calls would not affect the morale of the Taleban movement.
